title: Daily Sales Tracker
briefing:
Oh! Someone responded! Thank goodness...

I run a small bakery down on Main Street. I'm not very good with computers, but my nephew said I should track my daily numbers.

I just need help with some simple calculations. Nothing fancy! Just... storing numbers and doing basic math.

Can you help me?
description: Help Betty track her daily bakery sales and calculate profit.
successMessage:
Oh my goodness, thank you so much! This is wonderful!

Here's your payment. You did such a great job - my friend Mario who runs the pizza shop needs help too. Can I refer you to him?

*You completed your first gig!*

tasks.story:
I counted today's receipts. We made $450 in sales today.

I need to write that number down somewhere safe so I don't forget it.
tasks.guide:
Beep boop! ðŸ¤– I'm Chip, your AI coding assistant.

Betty needs to remember a number. In JavaScript, we use **variables** to store data.

Use the keyword `let` followed by the name `sales` to create a variable, and assign it the value `450`.
tasks.starterCode: // Store the sales amount with let

tests.name: Sales variable exists
tests.description: Check if sales variable is defined
tests.passMessage: Perfect! You stored the sales amount correctly.
tests.failMessage: Make sure to create a variable called 'sales' with the value 450 using 'let'.

tasks.story:
Oh dear, I missed a receipt under the register!

It wasn't $450, it was actually $460.

Can you fix that number for me?
tasks.guide:
Mistakes happen! Since we used `let`, we can change (or 'mutate') the value.

You don't need to write `let` again (that's only for creating new variables).

Just type the variable name `sales` and assign it the new value `460`.
tasks.starterCode:
// Update the existing sales variable
let sales = 450;

tests.name: Sales updated to 460
tests.passMessage: Great! You updated the variable without errors.

tasks.story:
Great! Now I also need to track my spending.

Today I spent $180 on ingredients and supplies. Can you write that down too?
tasks.guide:
New data means a new variable!

Create a variable named `costs` using `let` and set it to `180`.

tests.name: Costs variable exists
tests.description: Check if costs variable is defined
tests.failMessage: Create a variable called 'costs' with the value 180.

tasks.story:
Perfect! Now here's the important part...

I need to know my profit. That's just what I made in sales minus what I spent on costs.
tasks.guide:
Computers are great at math! ðŸ§®

Create a variable named `profit`.

Instead of typing the numbers again, you can do math with the variables themselves: `sales - costs`.

tests.name: Profit calculated correctly
tests.description: Check if profit equals sales - costs
tests.failMessage: Calculate profit by subtracting costs from sales: sales - costs

tasks.story:
One last thing! My rent is always the same: $2000. It never changes, month after month.

Can we put that in the system so it's safe?
tasks.guide:
Betty says this number never changes.

For values that shouldn't change (constants), we use the keyword `const` instead of `let`.

Declare `rent` using `const` and set it to `2000`.

tests.name: Rent defined with const
tests.description: Check if rent variable is defined as a constant
tests.passMessage: Perfect! You used const for the fixed value.
tests.failMessage: Make sure to create a variable called 'rent' with value 2000 using 'const'.
